title: Land developer Wolfdene lifts lot prices as demand surges
text:
“The lending policies that impacted residential real estate purchasers also put the brakes on developers looking to acquire and construct new projects," Mr Goldthorp said.

"Despite the significant improvement in these conditions, it will take 12 to 18 months for the delivery cycle to get enough flow-through to contribute to supply in a meaningful way."

Wolfdene recently beefed up its land bank after partnering with Chinese-backed Blueways Group to acquire a 42-hectare site in the city's north-west for $60 million.

Commenting on the latest surge in buying activity centred around its three flagship projects, Brompton and Pavilion in the south-east and Platform in the north, Mr Goldthorp said the conversion of inquiries to sales was back to 2017 levels.

He put this down to record low interest rates, a rise in Melbourne’s auction clearance rates above 70 per cent and a significant shift in media and buyer sentiment.

Mr Goldthorp said the price increases were the first significant sign of escalations since early 2018.

"It’s been a challenging 18 months, but the downturn was never about demand, it was regulatory led," he said.

Advertisement

"Once the federal election was run and won and APRA relaxed serviceability measures on loan applications, we were confident that a genuine market recovery would materialise in spring.

"Multiple interest rate cuts obviously helped, too."

On Monday, Stockland boss Mark Steinert said the developer was accelerating its lot production to make sure it could meet demand,

Mr Steinert said signs of a shortage of stock had become apparent in August "particularly in Sydney" and were starting to emerge in Brisbane as well.

Greater Melbourne accounts for about 40 per cent of the Australian land subdivision market.

According to a June quarter update from real estate group Oliver Hume, the gross or advertised median lot price for metropolitan Melbourne eased back to $312,000 having peaked at more than $330,000 in late 2018.

On average, incentives remain around $15,000 to $30,000 per lot although higher incentives are on offer in some estates, Oliver Hume said.

Lots took 60 days on average to sell during the June quarter, down from 87 in the first quarter of the year.

At the peak of the market – between early 2017 and mid-2018, when speculators and investors were highly active – lots were selling in 21 to 30 days.
description: Wolfdene managing director Michael Goldthorp said he agreed the country was heading towards an undersupply of housing.
